Mussels with tomato sauce.  Favorite dish here.
Grilled octopus with Korean BBQ sauce.  Surprisingly good combination.

review.des:
Tried for brunch. The bright, glass walled dining room is a good venue for brunch.

Duck chilaquiles were a tasty twist on this Mexican standard. The tortilla strips were appropriately al dente rather than being soggy or too crisp. A perfectly cooked sunny side up egg added some creaminess.

Bagles and lox was very good. Nice, smoky lox, and a healthy layer of chived cream cheese. Pro tip: order a side of bacon and add it for a special treat.

There is a limited cocktail menu and some nice wines by the glass.

Service was friendly and efficient.

Southern inspired modern American brunch (shrimp and grits, chicken and waffles, oyster pizza boy). It wasn't the most memorable meal, but I'd eat the fried chicken and waffles again. My sister loves oysters and thought these ones were great. Ambiance is elegant and posh. Nice place for upscale brunch.

-Sophisticated nautical-chic atmosphere.
-Hostess gave a little bit of a smug attitude at first, but turned out to be very nice.
-Bartender was very efficient and friendly--she was happy to give me some tastes of wine and some recommendations on the menu.
-Our waitress was pleasant and competent, but honestly a little overly formal.  It sometimes felt more like we were talking to a machine instead of a person.
-Their riff on deviled eggs was interesting--not quite deviled eggs, but fun--served in the eggshells with a smoked salmon mousse and salmon roe on top.  They were beautiful and very tasty.
-Oysters were fresh and delicious.  They did a great job of describing their profiles.  We got an east and west coast grouping.  They were very different, but both nice and tender with the right ocean brininess.  They were served with a great homemade mignonette sauce and the GT proprietary hot sauces.
-The smoked fish platter wasn't exactly what I was expecting--I was thinking it would be more like fish salads.  But it was actually more sophisticated--with small portions of smoked trout, smoked salmon and a really unusual and surprisingly enjoyable eel terrine.  They were served with fantastic herb crime fraiche, avocado mustard and thin crisp crostini.
-Lobster roll was excellent--warm buttery roll, generous amounts of lobster meat, not too much mayo--exactly what we wanted.  The fried onions it came with were addictive.
-Carrot cake dessert was decent--but the real star was the coconut ice cream that came with it.
-Pricing was honestly high for what we got.  A glass of Sancerre $15, New Zealand Sauv Blanc $14, "MP" on the lobster roll which is always kind of annoying--wholesale lobster isn't that expensive anymore, they should be able to give you a fixed price.  But we were willing to pay it, and we were satisfied with our meal.

First time here. We had reservations but it was crowded so we sat at the bar and started ordering.  It is a very popular place. We ordered the deviled eggs. Unique and tasty. Poke was plain but amazing. A hint of sesame oil and Mango. When we were seated we had the best crab cake ever. And Ouster sliders complimentary. OUR waiters Jerrod was smart and personable. Told us about the chief and other fun facts. The homemade pasta and claims and the scallops were the best we have ever had. 5 stars.
My favorite spot for awesome seasonal oysters when I'm downtown visiting.  The servers are great and attentive.  Menu selection and quality of the food keeps me coming back.

pics.caption: Hamachi Crudo and Tuna Poke, nice combo to enjoy.
Tuna Poke... They even have chopsticks if you ask.

review.des: I ordered Washington state oysters and clams from Virginia. The oysters were so good, fresh and cold. The clams were not as fresh, they weren't bad, but you could tell it had been probably a week or more since they were harvested. I also had the snapper ceviche and it lacked flavor. It was mostly radish?? (Some crunchy fruit or veggie) and avocado and very little fish, very little flavor. I'm surprised it was so expensive for what they had, but then again...a seafood restaurant in Chicago. Lol

The fish and seafood stuff are decent (fish and chips are passable). Very expensive and high end. I had a soda which was okay, forget what was in it. Extremely overpriced- sage syrup, lime and ginger beer. Skip it!

The one really odd thing about this place was how well thought-out and good the desserts are - seriously, just go here and order the dessert and share it. I had the PB & J panna cotta, which was filled with a lot of inventive flavors - grape jelly sorbet, sour grape slices, almost caramel-y peanut butter frosting, and two layers of panna cotta, one plainer, one peanut butter. And some peanut butter cookies. Balances really well. Also there was a passion fruit creme brulee, but the fruit parts were really too strong.

Ambience is very fancy and Rich.
We enjoy the food and the chicken waffles dish is so big that we are full stomach. Good service!And they also provide paper and crayons for kids!
Fresh and innovative. From the fresh ouster selection to a PB & J panda cotta dessert that Instill dream about, GT Fish & Oyster is at the top of my list. Enjoy!

pics.caption: So much goodness - the PB&J was the winner!

review.des:
Chicago is not exactly known for their seafood options but this is one of the few that I would recommend.  Been here twice and really enjoyed each time.

The 2nd best chowder I remember having was here with Pike's Place Chowder being the only place better.  The smokiness of the bacon is really the biggest difference.  Add some of their hot sauce to it and you have a delicious, smokey, creamy, spicy concoction.  Really hits the spot in winter!

Lobster roll is good, not great.  They do the NE style split roll which is essential to a good lobster roll IMO.  Oyster po'boy sliders are fantastic!

This place is a little pricey which is part of the reason I wouldn't put it at 5 stars.  Otherwise not too much to complain about.
I've been here twice and each time left with a happy belly.  The food is great and is best shared family style.

excellent. I'm honestly shocked that this place was under my nose this whole time, yet it took me this long to finally try it! We had all of the servers suggestions, which included the little oyster sliders. Um, wow. I could've eaten 20 of those alone. Also had the lobster rolls, SO delicious. The bun on the lobster roll was insanity. Love this place!

Went to GTFO for the first time yesterday to celebrate a birthday.

The two of us feasted on fresh and meaty crab cakes, jumbo shrimp cocktail (sauce was amazing!), soft and flavorful tuna poke, chilled fire-roasted broccoli, a massive caesar salad, perfectly cooked scallops, a few cocktails, and a rich slice of carrot cake.

The service was great. The atmosphere is what you would expect of something upscale but not overly exclusive or formal.

They even sent out a $20 gift card as a thank you for celebrating with them. Amazing!

The bill for drinks, many apps, entrees, and a shared dessert was under $140! Try matching this at any other Chicago seafood restaurant.

Also -- 1/2 off oysters after 9pm!

Yum! I went here during restaurant week for brunch. At first when I saw the restaurant week menu I thought it was going to be way to much food, but they cut the portion sizes down, so it was perfect. I started off with the Streusel monkey bread. I actually have to say I've had better, but for some reason I think the portion size did have something to do with it not being as tasty. I think if it was bigger it may have been more moist versus crispy, but that's just my opinion.  Next we had the breakfast sandwich, which was tasty. For the third entrée I chose the Chicken and waffles. Man that chicken was seasoned good and the waffles were sweet and fluffy. I would definitely head back to try the rest of the menu. Also, note it was a cute atmosphere too! Great place for brunch!
